story_prompt: The world ended 20 years ago, you haven't found a living soul since then. Through some ingenuity, you call voicemails for the last 20 years to keep you company. 'Hi, this is Cindy...' 'Hi you reached Bob' 'You know what to do at the beep' until one day 'Hello...hello? Oh my God hello!'

Response: 
Of course! Here are three major characters that I came up with based on the premise:
1. Bob - Bob is the most frequent caller on the voicemail system. He's been calling every day for the past 20 years, always starting with the same phrase "Hi, this is Bob." At first, he was excited and hopeful, thinking that someone might finally answer. Now, he's just going through the motions, hoping against hope that he'll finally find someone to talk to. Despite his initial enthusiasm, Bob has become increasingly despondent over the years. He's started to wonder if there's anyone else out there, and if so, why they haven't answered him. He's begun to question whether he'll ever find anyone, and he's filled with a deep sadness and loneliness.
2. Cindy - Cindy is another regular caller on the voicemail system. She's been leaving messages every day for the past 20 years, always starting with the phrase "Hi, this is Cindy." At first, she was excited to have someone to talk to, but over time her enthusiasm has worn off. She's started to feel like Bob, wondering if there's anyone else out there and why they haven't answered her. Cindy has become increasingly paranoid, convinced that there must be someone else out there who can hear her calls. She's afraid to leave her voice message in case it's the last chance she has to communicate with someone. Her thoughts are consumed by the fear of being alone forever.
3. Sarah - Sarah is a new caller on the voicemail system. She's been leaving messages for only a few days, but her enthusiasm is unwavering. She's excited to finally have someone to talk to, and she doesn't care that no one has answered her before. She's optimistic and cheerful, seeing the bright side of things even in the face of an empty voicemail box. Despite her positivity, Sarah is also filled with a sense of wonder and curiosity. She wants to know everything about the world and the people in it, and she's eager to learn as much as she can. As she continues to leave messages, Sarah will start to uncover clues about the past and the mysterious circumstances that led to the apocalypse.
output:
Story:
As I sat alone in my makeshift shelter, staring at the blank wall of the radio receiver, I couldn't help but feel a deep sense of loneliness. Twenty years had passed since the world ended, and not a single living soul had responded to my voicemails. Bob, Cindy, and Sarah were the only voices I had left to keep me company, and their messages were all starting to sound the same. Day after day, week after week, year after year, their voices remained the only constants in a world devoid of life.
At first, Bob's cheerful greetings had brought me hope. Maybe someone would finally pick up, and we could chat and get to know each other. But as the years went by, Bob's messages became less enthusiastic, more melancholic. He'd stop and pause before saying goodbye, as if he was searching for something that wasn't there. Cindy, too, had lost her initial excitement. Her voice dripped with paranoia, as if she feared that the last person on Earth was listening in on her calls. And Sarah, oh Sarah, her optimism was infectious at first. But now, her messages seemed more like a desperate plea for connection than a genuine attempt at communication.
I remembered the first time I heard a voice on the radio. It was like a spark of hope igniting in my chest. Maybe there was still someone out there, maybe there was still a world worth living in. But as the years went by, that spark died, replaced by the dull ache of solitude.
Sometimes, I wondered if it was all just a dream. If the world had never ended, and we were all just stuck in some kind of purgatory, reliving the same memories over and over again. The thought was both comforting and terrifying. Comforting because it meant that there was still a chance for a different outcome, but terrifying because it meant that this was all there was. No escape, no hope, just endless silence.
As I settled into my bedding, I couldn't shake off the feeling of hopelessness. I missed the world, I missed the sun on my face and the wind in my hair. I missed laughing and crying and hugging and kissing. I missed everything. And as I drifted off to sleep, I whispered to myself, hoping against hope that tomorrow would bring something different.
